text.content: Marketplace Home Page Design

rich_text.plain_text: Marketplace Home Page Design

text.content: The Marketplace Home Page is designed to focus attention on products (primarily) and storefronts (secondarily). The UI grids sit in the background as the image content remains in focus. Inside ProductCard components, product images are intentionally the largest visuals on the screen, to focus the user’s attention and entice them to click through to a product page. Each ProductCard component contains a “quick add to cart” button in the top right corner for impulse buyers.

text.content: I spent a lot of time trying to incorporate video reels into the marketplace home design. This ate up a lot of time, and didn’t end up in the final designs. It reiterated an important concept in design: start simple. I could have saved a lot of time by starting simple.

text.content: What I Learned

rich_text.plain_text: What I Learned

text.content: This was my first project designing around AI generative art. I learned a lot about how AI businesses are built, the thought processes behind combining old and new technology, and how to integrate an industry-standard design concept (like an eCommerce storefront) with an exponential technology (Generative AI). I learned a lot about Midjourney, decentralized production, auto layout in Figma, and building an online community around a shared interest.

I learned a lot about Midjourney, decentralized production, auto layout in Figma, and building an online community around a shared interest.

text.content: Gathering Content

rich_text.plain_text: Gathering Content

text.content: To begin, Crystal gathered all recent examples of her artwork into a shared Google Drive folder. This included photographs of her recent body paintings, illustrations, and generative AI artwork. I downloaded all the examples and uploaded them to an fresh Adobe Lightroom Catalogue. In Lightroom, we chose the top artworks in each category, and applied color correction to the photos so that they would be aesthetically pleasing as a whole. We compressed and exported the photos for quick loading on the web.

rich_text.plain_text: To begin, Crystal gathered all recent examples of her artwork into a shared Google Drive folder. This included photographs of her recent body paintings, illustrations, and generative AI artwork. I downloaded all the examples and uploaded them to an fresh Adobe Lightroom Catalogue. In Lightroom, we chose the top artworks in each category, and applied color correction to the photos so that they would be aesthetically pleasing as a whole. We compressed and exported the photos for quick loading on the web.

text.content: Creating the brand

rich_text.plain_text: Creating the brand

text.content: I asked Crystal to create a list of brand adjectives that she would like to resemble her brand. After a few brainstorming sessions, we solidified the list in the style guide sheet below. Together with ample samples of imagery, I was able to pick a serif font she loved (serif for maturity) and begin developing a color palette focused on simplicity, balance (shades of gray) and creativity (purple). Lastly we added subtle iridescent hues of pink, purple, and blue to the brand, to add a sense of cosmic wonder and harajuku-inspired element.

rich_text.plain_text: I asked Crystal to create a list of brand adjectives that she would like to resemble her brand. After a few brainstorming sessions, we solidified the list in the style guide sheet below. Together with ample samples of imagery, I was able to pick a serif font she loved (serif for maturity) and begin developing a color palette focused on simplicity, balance (shades of gray) and creativity (purple). Lastly we added subtle iridescent hues of pink, purple, and blue to the brand, to add a sense of cosmic wonder and harajuku-inspired element.

You can think of the structure as an artistic portfolio / shop structure hybrid, expressed in the “Shop” and “Recent Artworks” columns below. The main intention was to give Crystal everything she would need to establish a profitable online presence.

text.content: Contact Page Design

rich_text.plain_text: Contact Page Design

text.content: For the contact page, we went with a simple form for a name, email, phone number, and message. All bookings, inquiries, and general messages would come through this form, powered by Webflow. Fields are dark to draw attention to where the viewer should interact with the page. Half of the page is an image of my favorite of Crystal’s artworks, chosen for its quality and intricacy to suggest a professional tone for inquiries.

text.content: What I Learned

rich_text.plain_text: What I Learned

text.content: Working with artists is very challenging, as being so visually creative tends to come with a general lack of structure in thought processes. But when you provide high quality structure to their creative expression, the results are often amazing. You have to be careful while doing this though, as your job as a designer is to let their work shine, and not get in the way.

text.content: Product Offering Brainstorm

rich_text.plain_text: Product Offering Brainstorm

text.content: In September 2022, I was being my digital nomadic self, visiting Medellin, Colombia, where I met the other two co-founders of reserv. We spent weeks brainstorming how to use our combined blockchain development knowledge/experience to create a web2-like web3 product that solved for a real-world use case.

rich_text.plain_text: In September 2022, I was being my digital nomadic self, visiting Medellin, Colombia, where I met the other two co-founders of reserv. We spent weeks brainstorming how to use our combined blockchain development knowledge/experience to create a web2-like web3 product that solved for a real-world use case.

text.content: Eventually we landed on the concept of “reservations on the blockchain”. We chose this because we believed the verifiability, immutability, and proof of ownership of NFTs on the blockchain would translate well to buying and selling reservations. The idea was scalable, challenging, and exciting. It was something we all wanted to use in real life. “Reservations on the blockchain” led to the brand name “reserv”. It was slick, catchy, and relevant to the fundamental product offering. We would try to build a B2B2C platform.

rich_text.plain_text: Eventually we landed on the concept of “reservations on the blockchain”. We chose this because we believed the verifiability, immutability, and proof of ownership of NFTs on the blockchain would translate well to buying and selling reservations. The idea was scalable, challenging, and exciting. It was something we all wanted to use in real life. “Reservations on the blockchain” led to the brand name “reserv”. It was slick, catchy, and relevant to the fundamental product offering. We would try to build a B2B2C platform.

text.content: A few weeks in to designing the “reservations on the blockchain” UI / UX, we realized that the concept would be hard to sell. It was difficult determining a specific niche to target, and therefore difficult to go zero to one with a focused brand, marketing message, and target market.

rich_text.plain_text: A few weeks in to designing the “reservations on the blockchain” UI / UX, we realized that the concept would be hard to sell. It was difficult determining a specific niche to target, and therefore difficult to go zero to one with a focused brand, marketing message, and target market.

text.content: After consideration, we pivoted reserv to “ticketing on the blockchain”. This new concept was easier to brand, easier to explain, and easier to define target markets (event creators, music venues, conferences, exclusive parties). Personally, I was more excited about this direction because it was a way for me to combine my love for music and live events with a challenging project aimed at bringing real-world value to an exciting industry.

text.content: Brand Design

rich_text.plain_text: Brand Design

text.content: I took the concept of “ticketing on the blockchain” and created basic brand building blocks: logo, colors, personality, fonts, and icon library selection (Google Material Icons). The brand was attractive, mature, sexy, simple, legitimate, helpful, and easy. Gold was chosen as a primary color for its cultural relevance to hint luxury and attractiveness. Black as a primary backdrop was chosen for its elegance and allusion to nightlife.

text.content: Web Application Design - Event pages

rich_text.plain_text: Web Application Design - Event pages

text.content: Above all else, event page design and development was my primary focus. This is where our customer’s customer (event attendees) first experienced the product. First impressions needed to be perfect. The UX had to make sense, the UI had to impress, and the checkout process had to be seamless. If our customer’s customers were happy, then we knew our customer would be too.

rich_text.plain_text: Above all else, event page design and development was my primary focus. This is where our customer’s customer (event attendees) first experienced the product. First impressions needed to be perfect. The UX had to make sense, the UI had to impress, and the checkout process had to be seamless. If our customer’s customers were happy, then we knew our customer would be too.

text.content: The event pages intentionally displayed the most relevant information about the event first: the flyer, title, brand, date, time, location, image gallery, and about section. We also included the smart contract address for each event for web3 savvy individuals.

rich_text.plain_text: The event pages intentionally displayed the most relevant information about the event first: the flyer, title, brand, date, time, location, image gallery, and about section. We also included the smart contract address for each event for web3 savvy individuals.

text.content: Web Application Design - NFT Tickets

rich_text.plain_text: Web Application Design - NFT Tickets

text.content: Once purchased or claimed, NFT tickets and their accompanying QR codes were accessable anytime from the “Tickets” link in the left side navigation. The tickets view displayed relevant information about each ticket: event creator logo, ticket artwork,  ticket tier, ticket ID, event title, event date, event time, and redeemed status. Tapping on a ticket displayed the right side dynamic sheet, which displayed more information about the ticket, as well as the QR code denoting proof of ownership of the ticket (verified on the blockchain).

rich_text.plain_text: Once purchased or claimed, NFT tickets and their accompanying QR codes were accessable anytime from the “Tickets” link in the left side navigation. The tickets view displayed relevant information about each ticket: event creator logo, ticket artwork,  ticket tier, ticket ID, event title, event date, event time, and redeemed status. Tapping on a ticket displayed the right side dynamic sheet, which displayed more information about the ticket, as well as the QR code denoting proof of ownership of the ticket (verified on the blockchain).

text.content: When checking in to an event, all attendees displayed these QR codes to prove ownership of their NFT ticket. An event verifier would then scan the QR code, verify the legitimacy of the ticket on the Polygon blockchain, and grant the attendee access to the event.

rich_text.plain_text: When checking in to an event, all attendees displayed these QR codes to prove ownership of their NFT ticket. An event verifier would then scan the QR code, verify the legitimacy of the ticket on the Polygon blockchain, and grant the attendee access to the event.

We received constant positive feedback from both event creators and event attendees.

text.content: What Was Challenging

rich_text.plain_text: What Was Challenging

text.content: We began creating a product in an industry we knew very little about (event planning). Our initial assumptions on what mattered to event creators ended up being wrong, and therefore our initial product offerings didn’t align with what our target market actually needed.

rich_text.plain_text: We began creating a product in an industry we knew very little about (event planning). Our initial assumptions on what mattered to event creators ended up being wrong, and therefore our initial product offerings didn’t align with what our target market actually needed.

text.content: Researching the event industry, particularly getting access to decision makers and getting them to care.

rich_text.plain_text: Researching the event industry, particularly getting access to decision makers and getting them to care.

rich_text.plain_text: Explaining web3 benefits to web2 customers.

text.content: Molding a web3 system to the needs of web2 customers.

rich_text.plain_text: Molding a web3 system to the needs of web2 customers.

text.content: In general, almost no one pays to go to events. People usually receive free coupon codes / free tickets. This made it hard for us to come up with profitable pricing strategies.

rich_text.plain_text: In general, almost no one pays to go to events. People usually receive free coupon codes / free tickets. This made it hard for us to come up with profitable pricing strategies.

text.content: When your product don’t have an iOS or Android app, it’s very challenging to get people to remember who you are and where to sign in. Especially if your brand isn’t established yet.

rich_text.plain_text: When your product don’t have an iOS or Android app, it’s very challenging to get people to remember who you are and where to sign in. Especially if your brand isn’t established yet.

text.content: What I Learned

rich_text.plain_text: What I Learned

text.content: Always do enough research to determine if your idea is a product that you actually need to build. Make sure it solves a real problem before devoting months of your life it.

rich_text.plain_text: Always do enough research to determine if your idea is a product that you actually need to build. Make sure it solves a real problem before devoting months of your life it.

text.content: The intricacies of the ticketing industry, parity features of all ticketing apps, best practices in ticketing UX, etc.

rich_text.plain_text: The intricacies of the ticketing industry, parity features of all ticketing apps, best practices in ticketing UX, etc.

text.content: The main benefit event creators get from ticketing companies is actually marketing.

rich_text.plain_text: The main benefit event creators get from ticketing companies is actually marketing.

text.content: Event creators tend to rely on email marketing, rather than push notifications.

rich_text.plain_text: Event creators tend to rely on email marketing, rather than push notifications.

text.content: High ticket venues (night clubs, venues, etc) generally have multi-year contractual commitments with ticket companies. Ticket companies generally buy the right to be the sole ticketing provider for a venue. This made sales hard.

rich_text.plain_text: High ticket venues (night clubs, venues, etc) generally have multi-year contractual commitments with ticket companies. Ticket companies generally buy the right to be the sole ticketing provider for a venue. This made sales hard.

text.content: Explaining web3 benefits to web2 customers is very difficult and requires multi-touch point education efforts.

rich_text.plain_text: Explaining web3 benefits to web2 customers is very difficult and requires multi-touch point education efforts.

text.content: People really don’t like the word “NFT” in 2023.

rich_text.plain_text: People really don’t like the word “NFT” in 2023.

text.content: People do not expect to need to show their ticket upon entry if it was free (for free events).

rich_text.plain_text: People do not expect to need to show their ticket upon entry if it was free (for free events).

text.content: What I'd Do Differently

rich_text.plain_text: What I'd Do Differently

text.content: Strategically, I would have spent more time understanding the current problems of the ticketing industry, and determine if there was a real solution that we could build that would solve those problems. I would ensure that the product we built was demand-based. That it solved for common pain points rather than just “added value”.

text.content: Punta Brava is a luxury private golf and surf club located on the Pacific coast of the Baja Peninsula in Mexico. It's particularly known for its golf course, which is designed by legendary golfer Tiger Woods. By extension, Punta Brava Virtual Club is a member-led web3 virtual club representing the brand’s philanthropic arm. The virtual club focuses on philanthropy through securing donations for Punta Brava Medical (a Christian humanitarian organization) and Beyond the Brotherhood (a Navy SEALs post-active duty transition assistance program).

text.content: The TELx webapp is a community-focused web application interface that allows anyone to deposit LP Tokens into smart contracts to earn TEL rewards for providing liquidity to the Telcoin Platform. Users can connect their web3 wallet, stake their liquidity, and claim accrued rewards via blockchain calls. The webapp includes the list of TELx pools, a page for each pool, an accruing rewards section, about documentation, a web3 wallet sidebar, and a search function.

rich_text.plain_text: The TELx webapp is a community-focused web application interface that allows anyone to deposit LP Tokens into smart contracts to earn TEL rewards for providing liquidity to the Telcoin Platform. Users can connect their web3 wallet, stake their liquidity, and claim accrued rewards via blockchain calls. The webapp includes the list of TELx pools, a page for each pool, an accruing rewards section, about documentation, a web3 wallet sidebar, and a search function.

text.content: July 2021 - Now

text.content: TELx is the decentralized liquidity engine of the Telcoin Platform. It’s a group of liquidity pools composed of two or more crypto assets (for example, a pool of 50% TEL 50% USDC). As of this writing, there are 32 pools, all on the Polygon Network. TELx liquidity pools are used to power DeFi transactions on the Telcoin Platform, such as crypto trades.

text.content: TELx launched in May 2021. The release was successful, achieving the objective: a web-based portal to allowing users to provide liquidity to the Telcoin Platform and earn rewards. Since the release, all blockchain transactions have been consistent and reliable, and the web interface for staking performs as expected to industry standards.

rich_text.plain_text: TELx launched in May 2021. The release was successful, achieving the objective: a web-based portal to allowing users to provide liquidity to the Telcoin Platform and earn rewards. Since the release, all blockchain transactions have been consistent and reliable, and the web interface for staking performs as expected to industry standards.

text.content:
Only 1% of the global art market is Japanese-speaking (Japan). Around 83% of the global market is English and Chinese-speaking (USA, England, China). We believe there is a high, unmet demand for Japanese art in these countries.
We are creating Namonai as a platform that breaks the Japanese-English and Japanese-Chinese language barriers to give Japanese artists a fair chance to sell their art and 'make a name' for themselves globally.
At this stage, most of my efforts focus on UXUI Design and Frontend Development of Namonai's E-Commerce site. This case study will outline my approach and general thinking for this project.

text.content: Brand Design

rich_text.plain_text: Brand Design

text.content: Namonai branding is based on balance and simplicity. Our aim is to be as minimal as possible while still providing functional UX. This is to allow user artwork to shine. Namonai focuses on its artists, and therefore the brand should guide users to focus on the artists as well. Namonai is not pretentious or haughty. It's a helping hand.

text.content: Before designing a new website for the Japanese market, I needed to understand who I was designing for. The global luxury market has a very specific taste, and the Japanese luxury market has a niche taste. I learned that I was not designing for anyone under the age of 60, and that the decision-makers were in fact housewives with retired husbands and a large savings. They crave the exotic feeling of foreign luxury with the comfort of domestic familiarity. These wives treat themselves and their husbands to luxury British cruises around Japan. I developed Toshiko Sato, a respectable and mature Japanese woman who now wishes to enjoy the finer things in life with her husband.

text.content: The British version of the Cunard website had been recreated within the past year. Included in it were html elements with Cunard branded styles. And though the site did not include all components that we needed, it gave me a good idea of design definitions for fundamental elements like buttons, links, heading proportions, cards, carousels, spreads, and imagery. The grid and column definitions for the Japanese site are unique, as I ensured uniformity throughout mobile, tablet, and desktop designs. Sadly, I was not able to access any of the design files that they created in England, so I began building our own Sketch Brand Asset Library. Together with designer Junon Hwang, we also set the Japanese typefaces for Cunard Japan.

text.content: As with all cruise sites, the main of purpose of the former Cunard website was to allow users to search for cruises and learn about the Cunard brand. The Japanese version of the site had an extra distinction in that cruises were mainly of three types: those around Japan, those that are international (such as those through the Norwegian Fjords or through Southeast Asia), and those that circled the world. Thus, the UX design of the website needed to take these into consideration. In addition, other Japan-specific sections of the site needed to be considered such as new-grad recruiting, a newsroom, and special offers. All pages were completely redesigned.

text.content: You’ll notice that there is a lot of information on every page. This is one of the main distinctions between Japanese web design and ‘Western’ web design. While Western web design focuses only on the information that you need to make a decision, Japanese web design expects all information on one, very long page. In fact, when Japanese view Western designed websites, they often feel as if the design is ‘samishii’ or lonely due to the lack of information.

text.content: With ample consideration for the Japanese taste and a component library in Sketch, I was able to streamline the website’s UI design process. Altogether, I designed 24 main page layouts with desktop, tablet, and mobile versions in order to ensure that our partner development company had the specifications they needed to build a site to Cunard’s high expectations. After all, we were creating for one of the most revered luxury brands in the world. Due to the cruise information pages, the actual site has hundreds of pages. Because of time and financial constraints, we were not able to create a dynamic route module to map cruise routes dynamically, so I also created a few hundred custom map illustrations. Using my designs, the website was developed with a custom WordPress build.

text.content: Final Thoughts

rich_text.plain_text: Final Thoughts

text.content: The sheer volume of information I worked with on the Cunard.jp project provided a excellent challenge and has been the largest project I’ve ever worked on to date. In addition, all content and meetings were in Japanese which posed another challenge for me. The final site is comprehensive, and I am proud of the result. I learned a lot about not only web design, but also luxury business, Japanese localization, and pitching in a corporate setting.

From there he moved to Japan to work as a freelance Parkour & Movement Coach in order to spread what he learned while living in Europe.
projects.name: PKMASA Brand Design, English/Japanese  Wordpress Website Design and Development
projects.project_about: Masa asked me to create a logo and brand to help him promote his acrobatic teaching business and freelance performing. After creating a brand that we both loved, I then set up his bilingual (English and Japanese) Wordpress website that he can easily update and edit on his own.

text.content: PKMASA Brand Characteristics

rich_text.plain_text: PKMASA Brand Characteristics

text.content: The brand for PKMASA was a fun passion project for me, as I’ve always been interested in urban street culture. As Masa is an extremely talented urban Parkour artist at heart, I looked into other parkour brands to see the types of colors, fonts, and imagery that these brands have. Many used multiple shades of gray and one or two warm accent colors, assumably to represent the edginess but excitement of urban city life. We chose high contrast grays to represent the buildings of Tokyo, and a vibrant yellow color representing Masa’s tangible positivity and energy. The logo is a monkey, modeled after a screenshot of Masa from one of his parkour videos. He is knows as

text.content: PKMASA Homepage Desktop Design

rich_text.plain_text: PKMASA Homepage Desktop Design

text.content: The goal of Masa’s website was to showcase his acrobatic skills, allow people to see when he’s teaching, and get in contact with him for lessons. Masa’s students are both Japanese and non-Japanese, so the site must show both English and Japanese in order to cater to his target markets. He wanted to use the website to not only explain but also teach complicated topics such as parkour, Movement practice, conditioning, and acrobatic dancing. To achieve this, I designed and set up a custom Wordpress website for him so that he could continue to easily create and edit pages on these topics. As of this writing, the website has around 30-40 pages.

text.content: Final Thoughts

rich_text.plain_text: Final Thoughts

text.content: Helping Masa solidify his brand image and create a digital hub for his knowledge and offerings was a rewarding experience. I am very happy with the brand. As this was one of the first Wordpress websites I made customizing an existing template and page builder Elementor, working with the builder is challenging. While this allows Masa to create any page layout he’d like on his own, I believe the design suffers. Therefore, I learned how to balance design with “business requirements”. Either way, Masa loves his website.

Website

SIRUP is a Japanese R&B / Hip Hop singer based in Tokyo. His YouTube music videos have gathered millions of views. Unknown to many, SIRUP had actually been a famous singer in Japan already, and this new name is a rebrand.  Going off of a logo, we helped design the online SIRUP experience from scratch with a website that was easily maintainable, stylish, responsive, and ready to market his great music. We chose Wordpress because:

singlePages.name: About
singlePages.overview: Digital Designer, Frontend Developer, and Digital Producer with nine+ years of professional experience in the US, Japan, and China.

text.content: Josh is a seasoned digital designer, frontend engineer, and digital producer. With nine+ years of professional experience spanning the United States, Japan, and China, he now resides in Miami, Florida, where he serves full-time as VP Design at Telcoin.

rich_text.plain_text: Josh is a seasoned digital designer, frontend engineer, and digital producer. With nine+ years of professional experience spanning the United States, Japan, and China, he now resides in Miami, Florida, where he serves full-time as VP Design at Telcoin.

text.content: Josh's overarching mission is to enhance the lives of 1,000,000 individuals by addressing complex challenges with straightforward digital design and application solutions.

rich_text.plain_text: Josh's overarching mission is to enhance the lives of 1,000,000 individuals by addressing complex challenges with straightforward digital design and application solutions.

text.content: Industry Experience

rich_text.plain_text: Industry Experience

text.content: Josh has designed and coded 30+ digital products, websites, and apps, for company sizes ranging from multinational corporations to budding startups across a variety of sectors. Some examples of sectors include eCommerce, investment banking, data analytics, telecommunications, food & beverage, music, entertainment, art commerce, blockchain, decentralized finance, and web3. He is incredibly passionate about the intersection of AI, blockchain, and finance.

text.content: Personal History

rich_text.plain_text: Personal History

text.content: Born in Okinawa, Japan, to a military family, Josh relocated to the United States when he was just two years old. His childhood was spent in many states, including North Carolina, Alaska, California, Florida, and Minnesota. Always a creative spirit, his teenage years were filled with musical endeavors and a foray into small business through 20+ part-time roles, ranging from freelance photography to bartending to English teaching.

rich_text.plain_text: Born in Okinawa, Japan, to a military family, Josh relocated to the United States when he was just two years old. His childhood was spent in many states, including North Carolina, Alaska, California, Florida, and Minnesota. Always a creative spirit, his teenage years were filled with musical endeavors and a foray into small business through 20+ part-time roles, ranging from freelance photography to bartending to English teaching.

text.content: Uncertain about his career direction, Josh began his academic journey in business school in 2010, eventually settling on an undergraduate degree in marketing. This choice allowed him to merge his passion for design and branding with the intricacies of psychology to solve real business goals. Concurrently, he began freelancing, designing marketing materials and websites that drew from the marketing principles he was studying.

This choice allowed him to merge his passion for design and branding with the intricacies of psychology to solve real business goals. Concurrently, he began freelancing, designing marketing materials and websites that drew from the marketing principles he was studying.

text.content: Upon earning his BS degree in Marketing from the University of Minnesota Carlson School of Management, Josh's wanderlust led him back to his birthplace, Japan. In 2014, he enrolled in a bilateral exchange program at Sophia University in Tokyo, immersing himself in the Japanese language and the nuances of Japanese business culture.

rich_text.plain_text: Upon earning his BS degree in Marketing from the University of Minnesota Carlson School of Management, Josh's wanderlust led him back to his birthplace, Japan. In 2014, he enrolled in a bilateral exchange program at Sophia University in Tokyo, immersing himself in the Japanese language and the nuances of Japanese business culture.

text.content: Post-graduation, Josh secured a position as a web designer and frontend engineer at Rakuten's Creative Web Department in Tokyo. Over the next four to five years, he ventured into various roles in the Japanese tech, finance, and advertising sectors, even establishing his own freelance business. However, feeling he had reached a professional plateau, Josh returned to the U.S. in 2020, eager to tap into the tech industry's vast opportunities.

text.content: In early 2021, Telcoin brought him on board as their Head of Design. He’s since been promoted to VP Design. In this role, Josh has cultivated a profound appreciation for blockchain and its potential, particularly in decentralized finance and web3. Since joining Telcoin we has led the design of their  webapps, and mobile iOS/Android app, and brand, while concurrently producing and managing all of Telcoin’s webapps.

text.content: Hobbies

rich_text.plain_text: Hobbies

text.content: When Josh isn’t designing or developing, he enjoys studying macroeconomics via Real Vision, exploring AI businesses and tools, organizing his thoughts in Notion, and learning from mentors. He goes to the gym every day, attends yoga on weekends, and loves capturing fading moments through his photography. Josh speaks Japanese with business level proficiency and is studying to do the same in Spanish. You can generally find him attending DJ events (house, bass, deep house, hardstyle) on weekends with his friends in Miami. He has 6 tattoos, a pet bearded dragon, and no car.
